posts.name: FlooferLand!
posts.cooked:
The current state of the desktop app is awful, especially the theming situation. It looks and feels so bad it lend me to believe I downloaded an unofficial desktop port of Signal that has 10 stars on Github.
I like Signal, and I’d like to use it because Telegram is honestly killing itself off. But the desktop client for this app is so bad its making me prefer Telegram and their ad-infested desktop client.

Theming matters a lot in showing your brand’s identity, and this client does not feel like a comfy friendly place I could chat and meet friends on. This client feels very monotone and clinical, like it screams its some place I’d discuss crypto-related scandals and buy NFTs on while talking to my 50 year old co-workers about what new company we should hold for ransom. Does not feel like a place I’d talk with friends on about some new movie or game coming out.
Telegram’s client feels unprofessional in a friendly way, highly customizable, comfortable, and ad-infested but we’ll ignore that part.
This client feels monotone, following some Google Material design I’ve seen in 50 other apps, off-brand, and very uninspired. This app’s UI art style has no identity and feels poorly thrown together. It bothers me and many users.

This client looks and feels less official than Telegram’s unofficial community-built clients, and it feels like it hasn’t seen the light of a git commit in years despite it being actively well maintained.

I’d go as far as recommending a full rewrite, as a lot of people have already been requesting ditching Electron and rewriting the app in Qt or Tauri in another thread. The desktop client has a lot of problems besides “it lacks theming support and it’s ugly” (even though it is), such as the fact it barely has any settings, the fact it requires you to use your phone to sign in or make an account. Wallpapers are also not supported, which are supported in the mobile apps … this is a parity feature that is so easy to implement I could do it in 10-20 minutes.

UI identity and art style is another fight Telegram wins, and I do not want Telegram to win it.
Give Signal the desktop client it deserves

posts.name: FlooferLand!
posts.cooked:
For the default theme I have a couple ideas that could make it better and more friendly/unique

I’d recommend:

  • Getting rid of the menu bar at the top left on Windows & Linux, making it be a dropdown menu when you click the signal logo. I’d also recommend maybe making a title (window control) bar a non-native one with the native one being optional.
  • Making everything slightly bigger by default, and making the tab icons on the left less horizontally spread out (its very asymmetrical)
  • Optionally getting rid of the “Chats”, “Calls”, “Stories” in the top left and getting rid of that bar entirely, combining the new chat and new call functions with the search bar. The padding/margins are also very inconsistent in that top left section.
  • Generally making the UI feel less cluttered, which is basically what my recommendations are up until this point.
  • I’d recommend perhaps having some form of theme colour. Discord tints every grey towards a slight blue or red, and Telegram straight up makes everything blue. I’d recommend making the greys a bit darker on everything except the chat panel so there’s more contrast and it feels a bit more sleek

For the settings menu I’d recommend a complete redesign, because having it open up a separate unresizable window feels out of the ordinary compared to platforms like Discord and Telegram, and even compared to Signal, as clicking on your profile picture presents your profile inside a virtual popup inside the main Signal window.
The buttons on the left also have no hover effect, and the window generally feels clunky and inconsistent (it even flashes white when it’s open, even on a mid-spec system. its common practice to hide a window until electron detects the content loaded)
I’d recommend going the Telegram / Signal mobile app route by making the settings pop up in a virtual popup that only shows the settings categories; when clicked, showing the settings from the respective category you clicked on.

Those are all tweaks I feel would separate Signal from that sterile GitHub Desktop theme and make the interface look cleaner and less cluttered.
Though, adding in theming and background images alone would go a long way. (especially the background images)
There could even be some official user theme browser inside the app itself, which is something even Telegram doesn’t do.

I’ve also found Signal in general to be lacking settings and customization on both desktop and mobile. The settings and “your profile” menus feel particularly empty, especially/specifically on desktop.
If you compare Signal’s privacy settings page with Telegram’s privacy settings page it’s like a night and day difference. Signal in general lacks settings, and even though I haven’t noticed I’m missing anything as I haven’t been using Signal much, it just feels weird and makes Signal and the desktop client feel underdeveloped.

FlooferLand:

Signal in general lacks settings, and even though I haven’t noticed I’m missing anything as I haven’t been using Signal much, it just feels weird and makes Signal and the desktop client feel underdeveloped.

That is due to Signal’s development philosophy:

Development Ideology

The answer is not more options

Source:

Development Ideology Announcements
Truths which we believe to be self-evident: The answer is not more options. If you feel compelled to add a preference that’s exposed to the user, it’s very possible you’ve made a wrong turn somewhere. The user doesn’t know what a key is. We need to minimize the points at which a user is exposed to this sort of terminology as extremely as possible. There are no power users. The idea that some users “understand” concepts better than others has proven to be, for the most part, false. If anyt…

Edit: I don’t mind the look and feel of the desktop app. It does its job and is fine to use with macOS and Linux. But I don’t care for theming and wallpapers within apps. I just use apps mostly as they are.

FlooferLand:

Getting rid of the menu bar at the top left on Windows & Linux,

Do you mean the menu bar with ‘File’, ‘Edit’, ‘View’, ‘Window’ and ‘Help’? For the Linux app you can disable them. I don’t know for Windows, because I don’t use it.

posts.name: FlooferLand!
posts.cooked:
Welp, 2 points of Signal’s development philosophy appear to be majorly flawed.

People love customization, changing their software to make it better fit them. There are VLC Media Player power users and its the number one reason a literal media player has theming and extension support. A FLIPPIN MEDIA PLAYER.
I’ve seen people risk breaking the desktop app just to add in some form of theming, eagerly awaiting Signal to add in theming officially.
Power users exist, users on other platforms such as Discord will risk getting banned just to theme and have access to plugins and extra settings. If Signal were to launch an extension/theming platform, there would be plenty users making extensions and themes even just for themselves. Those are power users.

The majority of Linux users are power-users.
You could maybe even count most Signal users in general as power users, using a less mainstream chatting app for the sake of privacy is a bit of a power-usery thing to do.

Not everyone cares about theming, but it’s something that is always cared about regardless of the app. If someone uses an app for a long time, it’s very common to want the app to feel and look like whatever they consider as better. It’s why you make your real life room look the way it does, because you spend a lot of time in it.
A lot of Signal contributors likely use theming in their IDEs. Contributors are also power users.

There’s an option to disable the menu bar regardless of platform, I reckoned it should be disabled by default. Especially since this app makes the menu bar show on hover even when its hidden (which is actually very cool I’ve never seen it done anywhere else, no requirement to hold the alt key)
Though, it tends to sometimes stick around after alt+tabbing in and out of the app like it was never hidden in the first place.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: I’ve come to apologize. It does look bad.

I miss only two features; my question to the Signal devs:
Why the desktop client doesn’t support background images like the Android client?
And why there is no scheduled sending as the android app has?

I like the KISS principle. I don’t want all the features other messengers have.
But an individual background picture for chat rooms is not only more beautiful, it helps also to recognise (…I am in…) the right chat room/that’s the right contact.

In other words: it can help to avoid writing the wrong person, because of mixing up two chats.
So it’s a little nice security feature, easy to deploy (use the code of the android client!?).

Regarding the scheduled messages: I would guess it’s more complicated to implement this on desktop, because there is no unified way to do scheduling on all systems. So the App would have to do it internally which makes it necessary to have Signal Desktop running at the scheduled time or it wouldn’t send the message. If this is not done in a sensible way, it could lead to a lot of confusion and bad UX.

Related post about UI padding / spacing.

They should first fix how it looks first, imo. Theming after that makes more sense.

posts.cooked:
I’m a new Signal user (donated too), switched from Facebook Messenger and Apple’s Messages app, so I’m going to be discussing exclusively the Mac app here.

I don’t agree that the desktop app is as bad as you described at all (maybe because I don’t customize the theme):

FlooferLand:

This client feels very monotone and clinical, like it screams its some place I’d discuss crypto-related scandals and buy NFTs

Are we even using the same app?! The Signal desktop app is plain and minimalist, which is awesome. (Perhaps back in 2024, the app looked completely different—I wouldn’t know, though.)

That said, I would say the app feels kind of “half-baked” due to the issues I outlined in my post here: macOS app: Substitutions & inline predictions for the text box

It doesn’t feel native like, for example, Facebook Messenger’s Mac app does. I’ve read that Signal’s desktop app is Electron, and I’m not sure if Facebook Messenger is as well, but from an average, non-programmer user’s standpoint, going from macOS’s Messages and FB Messenger to the Signal desktop app feels like a downgrade in terms of typing experience.

I’m not sure how bootstrapped Signal’s dev team is, and I’m grateful there’s at least a desktop app for both Mac and Windows (wouldn’t have switched if it didn’t), but the desktop app could use some love for sure.

Herohtar:

Why don’t you do it then? The desktop team is more than willing to accept PRs. Then the client would be that much better for everyone.

Unfortunately, I can’t agree with you on that. My PR is still open there for a year or two. A simple CSS fix, they didn’t even close it. I believe they just forgot about that one. But to be honest, it’s harder to review PRs than to fix it by yourself. Also, making some theming and design choices would definitely need their design team to approve that. So I would say PR would be rather a waste of time in this case.

FlooferLand:

do it in 10-20 minutes.

This can’t be done in 10-20 minutes, though. Building UI components to look normal and modern, creating assets, and ensuring an overall good design takes a significant amount of time.

I too would appreciate at the very least, Feature parity with the android app, and i wholly agree that the desktop app feels amateurish. it feels like it ascribes to the Gnome ethos of “don’t give the user features, theyre too stupid to know how to use them”
You should always assume your users are smart enough to use your software.

I am not skilled enough to develop software, but as someone who has been using computers heavily for 25+ years, I do know what good software feels like. The desktop app is stable, it is functional, but it feels incomplete.
There’s a lot of dead space in the UI, theres no background images, theres no theme adjustments besides color. User icons are too big and too spaced out in the sidebar, i would ilke the option of an IRC style chat log , or enabling absolute message timestamps for each indivdual message (And not just the last one in a group).
I have some other nit picks, but they are nit picks. I just hope that it becomes a piece of software that I can tailor to my desired use.

Make the default experience usable for the vast majority of users who change nothing, but its never a bad idea to expose extra features and advanced config options to the users that want it. Always give your user choice and agency in their computing experience. You are not Apple, please dont turn into that. Allowing users to customize their experience is not “dangerous” or “misguided”. its Respect. You cannot please everyone, or even come close, so giving options makes the most people happy. I’d even love to see some native theming ability, it would be really nice if i could make it look integrated with my desktop environment. as it stands now, it sticks out like a sore thumb.
